name: Chicken Katsu
description: Chicken Katsu is a classic Japanese home-cooked dish served with tonkatsu sauce and a side of shredded cabbage salad. These tender and crispy panko-breaded cutlets are surprisingly easy to make, even on a busy weeknight! They also freeze well and make for a delicious meal-prep item.¬†

video.description:
Chicken Katsu is a classic Japanese home-cooked meal served with tonkatsu sauce and a side of shredded cabbage salad. These tender and crispy panko-breaded cutlets are surprisingly easy to make, even on a busy weeknight! They also freeze well and make for a delicious meal prep menu.¬†

PRINT RECIPE ‚ñ∂ https://www.justonecookbook.com/chicken-katsu/

INGREDIENTS

1 piece boneless, skinless chicken breast (9.5 oz or 270 g; you can also use the same weight of chicken thighs or tenders)
¬Ω tsp kosher/sea salt (I use Diamond Crystal; use half for table salt)
‚Öõ tsp freshly ground black pepper
1 large egg (50 g each w/o shell)
¬Ω Tbsp neutral-flavored oil (vegetable, rice bran, canola, etc) (for the egg)
3 Tbsp all-purpose flour (plain flour)
1 cup (60 g) panko (Japanese breadcrumbs)
3 cups (720 ml) neutral-flavored oil (vegetable, rice bran, canola, etc) (for deep frying; you should have 1.5 inches (3.8 cm) of oil in the pot)

To Serve
Tonkatsu Sauce (for drizzling over chicken katsu; you can also make my homemade tonkatsu sauce: https://www.justonecookbook.com/tonkatsu-sauce-recipe/)
shredded cabbage (optional)
Japanese sesame dressing (optional)
tomato (optional)

INSTRUCTIONS with step-by-step pics ‚ñ∂ https://www.justonecookbook.com/chicken-katsu/

#chickenkatsu #„ÉÅ„Ç≠„É≥„Ç´„ÉÑ #justonecookbook

How to Make Japanese Chicken Curry (Recipe) „ÉÅ„Ç≠„É≥„Ç´„É¨„Éº„ÅÆ‰Ωú„ÇäÊñπ („É¨„Ç∑„Éî)

recipeIngredient: 3 cups neutral oil ((for deep-frying; enough for 1¬Ω inches (3.8 cm) of oil in the pot))
1  large egg (50 g each w/o shell)
tonkatsu sauce ((or make my Homemade Tonkatsu Sauce))

itemListElement.text: If you prefer not to deep-fry, see my recipe for Baked Chicken Katsu.
itemListElement.name: If you prefer not to deep-fry, see my recipe for Baked Chicken Katsu.

itemListElement.text: Butterfly the chicken breast so the meat is thinner and cooks faster; read more details in my blog post. To butterfly the chicken breast, split it horizontally from the side (stopping before you cut all the way through it) and open it like a book. When you open the breast, the two sides will mirror each other, resembling a butterfly (see how in my video). Here, I‚Äòd also like to demonstrate the Japanese cutting technique Kannon biraki (Ë¶≥Èü≥Èñã„Åç) to butterfly the chicken breast. With a sharp knife, score the middle of 1 piece boneless, skinless chicken breast from the top about halfway through the thickness of the breast; do not cut completely through.
itemListElement.name: Butterfly the chicken breast so the meat is thinner and cooks faster; read more details in my blog post. To butterfly the chicken breast, split it horizontally from the side (stopping before you cut all the way through it) and open it like a book. When you open the breast, the two sides will mirror each other, resembling a butterfly (see how in my video). Here, I‚Äòd also like to demonstrate the Japanese cutting technique Kannon biraki (Ë¶≥Èü≥Èñã„Åç) to butterfly the chicken breast. With a sharp knife, score the middle of 1 piece boneless, skinless chicken breast from the top about halfway through the thickness of the breast; do not cut completely through.

itemListElement.text: Then, turn the knife parallel to the cutting board and slice the chicken from the center toward the left side (or the right side, if you‚Äòre left-handed) to make it evenly thin. Stop before you cut all the way through it, and open it like a book. Imagine we‚Äòre creating a French door here.
itemListElement.name: Then, turn the knife parallel to the cutting board and slice the chicken from the center toward the left side (or the right side, if you‚Äòre left-handed) to make it evenly thin. Stop before you cut all the way through it, and open it like a book. Imagine we‚Äòre creating a French door here.

itemListElement.text: Turn the chicken 180 degrees and butterfly the second side from the center toward the left, creating another ‚Äúdoor.‚Äú
itemListElement.name: Turn the chicken 180 degrees and butterfly the second side from the center toward the left, creating another ‚Äúdoor.‚Äú

itemListElement.text: Cut the chicken in half down the center. Now you have two pieces.
itemListElement.name: Cut the chicken in half down the center. Now you have two pieces.

itemListElement.text: With a meat mallet or the back of the knife, pound the chicken to an even thickness, about ¬º to ¬Ω inch (6 mm to 1.3 cm).
itemListElement.name: With a meat mallet or the back of the knife, pound the chicken to an even thickness, about ¬º to ¬Ω inch (6 mm to 1.3 cm).

itemListElement.text: Season both sides of the chicken with ¬Ω tsp Diamond Crystal kosher salt and ‚Öõ tsp freshly ground black pepper.
itemListElement.name: Season both sides of the chicken with ¬Ω tsp Diamond Crystal kosher salt and ‚Öõ tsp freshly ground black pepper.

recipeInstructions.name: To Heat the Oil and Bread the Chicken

itemListElement.text: Add 3 cups neutral oil to a medium-size, heavy-bottomed pot (I use a Staub 2.75 QT Dutch oven, 11 inches in diameter). Add enough oil so it is 1¬Ω inches (3.8 cm) deep in the pot; dip a chopstick in the oil to measure. If you use a large pot, you will need to add more oil to get it 1¬Ω inches deep. Start heating the oil to 340¬∫F (170¬∫C) over medium-low heat (or low heat, if you need more time to bread the chicken). For the breading, prepare three bowls or trays: One with 3 Tbsp all-purpose flour (plain flour), one with 1 cup panko (Japanese breadcrumbs), and one with 1 large egg (50 g each w/o shell).
itemListElement.name: Add 3 cups neutral oil to a medium-size, heavy-bottomed pot (I use a Staub 2.75 QT Dutch oven, 11 inches in diameter). Add enough oil so it is 1¬Ω inches (3.8 cm) deep in the pot; dip a chopstick in the oil to measure. If you use a large pot, you will need to add more oil to get it 1¬Ω inches deep. Start heating the oil to 340¬∫F (170¬∫C) over medium-low heat (or low heat, if you need more time to bread the chicken). For the breading, prepare three bowls or trays: One with 3 Tbsp all-purpose flour (plain flour), one with 1 cup panko (Japanese breadcrumbs), and one with 1 large egg (50 g each w/o shell).

itemListElement.text: Add ¬Ω Tbsp neutral oil to the egg and whisk it together. Tip: By adding oil, the meat and breading won‚Äôt detach from each other while cooking and the juice and flavor from the meat will not escape easily.
itemListElement.name: Add ¬Ω Tbsp neutral oil to the egg and whisk it together. Tip: By adding oil, the meat and breading won‚Äôt detach from each other while cooking and the juice and flavor from the meat will not escape easily.

itemListElement.text: Coat the chicken with the flour and shake off any excess. Then, coat it with the beaten egg.
itemListElement.name: Coat the chicken with the flour and shake off any excess. Then, coat it with the beaten egg.

itemListElement.text: Finally, coat the chicken with the panko, pressing the panko into the cutlet so that it adheres well. Remove any excess. Repeat with the remaining chicken piece.
itemListElement.name: Finally, coat the chicken with the panko, pressing the panko into the cutlet so that it adheres well. Remove any excess. Repeat with the remaining chicken piece.

itemListElement.text: If you are new to deep-frying, read my How to Deep Fry Food page and get an instant-read thermometer to check the oil temperature. Heat the oil to 340¬∫F (170¬∫C). I use medium heat throughout deep-frying, but please increase or decrease the heat to maintain the target oil temperature.
itemListElement.name: If you are new to deep-frying, read my How to Deep Fry Food page and get an instant-read thermometer to check the oil temperature. Heat the oil to 340¬∫F (170¬∫C). I use medium heat throughout deep-frying, but please increase or decrease the heat to maintain the target oil temperature.

itemListElement.text: When, the oil is at the correct temperature, add one piece of breaded chicken. Fry one piece at a time. Deep-fry for a total of¬†3 minutes, turning the chicken once at the halfway point. Tip: Do not overcrowd the pot. Remember, your ingredients should take up no more than about half of the oil surface area at any one time. If you add too much food at once, the temperature of the oil will drop quickly and the chicken will absorb too much oil.
itemListElement.name: When, the oil is at the correct temperature, add one piece of breaded chicken. Fry one piece at a time. Deep-fry for a total of¬†3 minutes, turning the chicken once at the halfway point. Tip: Do not overcrowd the pot. Remember, your ingredients should take up no more than about half of the oil surface area at any one time. If you add too much food at once, the temperature of the oil will drop quickly and the chicken will absorb too much oil.

itemListElement.text: Deep-fry until both sides are golden brown. Remove the cutlet from the oil and hold it vertically over the pot for a few seconds to drain the excess oil. Then, transfer it to a wire rack or paper towel-lined tray. If possible, keep it on its side to drain the excess oil.
itemListElement.name: Deep-fry until both sides are golden brown. Remove the cutlet from the oil and hold it vertically over the pot for a few seconds to drain the excess oil. Then, transfer it to a wire rack or paper towel-lined tray. If possible, keep it on its side to drain the excess oil.

itemListElement.text: Collect all the crumbs in the oil with a fine-mesh skimmer before you add the next piece of chicken. If you don‚Äôt clean up these crumbs, they will burn and the oil will get darker. Make sure to keep the oil clean throughout deep-frying.
itemListElement.name: Collect all the crumbs in the oil with a fine-mesh skimmer before you add the next piece of chicken. If you don‚Äôt clean up these crumbs, they will burn and the oil will get darker. Make sure to keep the oil clean throughout deep-frying.

itemListElement.text: Cut the chicken into 1-inch (2.5 cm) pieces and serve it with tonkatsu sauce. Typically, I serve Chicken Katsu with a side of shredded green cabbage and my Japanese Sesame Dressing. I also add a few wedges of tomato for color.
itemListElement.name: Cut the chicken into 1-inch (2.5 cm) pieces and serve it with tonkatsu sauce. Typically, I serve Chicken Katsu with a side of shredded green cabbage and my Japanese Sesame Dressing. I also add a few wedges of tomato for color.

itemListElement.text: You can store the leftovers in an airtight container and store them in the refrigerator for up to 2 days or in the freezer for up to a month. To reheat, bake at 350¬∫F (180¬∫C) for 15‚Äì20 minutes for chicken katsu that was thawed in the refrigerator overnight, or for 30 minutes if heating directly from frozen. Check that the inside is warm before serving.
itemListElement.name: You can store the leftovers in an airtight container and store them in the refrigerator for up to 2 days or in the freezer for up to a month. To reheat, bake at 350¬∫F (180¬∫C) for 15‚Äì20 minutes for chicken katsu that was thawed in the refrigerator overnight, or for 30 minutes if heating directly from frozen. Check that the inside is warm before serving.

review.reviewBody: Love this recipe and our family has been using it since we first found it a year ago! We‚Äôve found that using that bit of oil in the eggs really does help! (Though, I‚Äôve always wondered WHY the oil works so well.)
Instead of deep fry, would a shallow fry in a skillet work?
This recipe was amazing! I have never deep fried before, but this still turned out crispy and delicious. I also made the Tonkatsu sauce, which was equally great.
excellent recipe, my chicken katsu turned out super crispy! thanks Nami
I made the chicken Katsu and homemade Tonkatsu Sauce tonight for dinner. It was so easy and absolutely delicious. I will definitely be making it again!

Excellent recipe!  Homemade tonkatsu sauce is spot on.  I made the mistake of (not following the recipe) blending the sesame dressing in a blender instead of whisking it together, so it was a bit thicker, but the flavor is nice.
At the end of the video there is a small jar of sauce (not the salad dressing) in the corner. What is that? I thought it was the tonkatsu sauce but you poor that directly out of bottle.
